Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Integrating genetic, taxonomic, and functional diversity of tetrapods across the Americas and through extinction risk
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines continent-wide variation in the dimensions of biodiversity. New data are collected on the biodiversity and extinction risk of 2,500 Western Hemisphere reptile species. These data are combined with existing data for mammals, birds, and amphibians to measure and map the diversity of all 13,000 terrestrial vertebrate species of the Americas, in three dimensions. The first is phylo-temporal diversity, measuring the genetically distinctiveness of the species in an area. The second is compositional diversity, measuring which species occur in an area. And the third is trait diversity, measuring how the species in an area vary in place, food, time, and size niches. For each of the three dimensions, measures will reflect differences over space (dissimilarity). All data will be published in open access databases.

The research is important scientifically in representing novel, hemisphere-wide analysis of the genetic, taxonomic, and functional diversity of a major species group. This will allow determination of relationships among the three dimensions of biodiversity, and, by using the extinction risk data, prediction of impending changes in these relationships. These analyses have important practical implications, because the degree to which the dimensions covary will determine the efficiency possible in their conservation. Our PI institutions comprise four universities and the non-governmental organization NatureServe, the latter of which provides a channel for incorporation of results into conservation decisions, as well as providing real-world exposure to the two postdoctoral associates, and three graduate and approximately 40 undergraduate students, who the project will employ. The project includes significant international capacity building through Red List workshops in Brazil, Costa Rica, Ecuador, and Chile, along with research coordination meetings in Brazil. Both students and PIs will be traveling and collaborating with in-country scientists during these meetings, with support provided by the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The diversity of life on Earth can be divided into three components, also known as dimensions:

1) The diversity of species

2) The diversity of ancestral relationships

3) The diversity of ecological functions

Our reserach centered around these aspects of diversity in the tetrapods - birds, mammals, reptiles and amphibians - of the Americas.

A major question addressed was the age-old conundrum of why there are more species in the tropics than in other regions like the temperature zone. The scientific debate has focused on ecological versus evolutionary explanations for this pattern. The ecological hypothesis reasons that the tropics have no winters and abundant rainfall and sunshine leading to great plant growth, which in turn provides more opportunities for species to coexist. The evolutionary hypothesis states that due to relative climate stability, species in the tropics have had more time to evolve and diversify into different niches than in temperate and arctic regions where frequent glaciations over geological history have prevented long periods of climate stability when species can diversify. An analysis of the three dimensions of biodiversity for tetrapods revealed strong support for the evolutionary hypothesis in explaining why there are so many more species in the tropics – they simply have had more time to diversify there.

Humans have inhabited the Americas for at least 12,000 years, during which time they have hunted prey and altered landscapes. Have they significantly altered the animal communities we observe today? By relating animal body size to local environmental conditions, we could determine whether current animal communities contain species that are the expected average body size. Body size is a good indicator of ecological function. In fact, there is a widespread pattern of tetrapods being smaller than expected throughout the hemisphere. This finding highlights a pervasive signature of human impacts on animal communities. Evidently hunting and land use change have caused the larger animals to become scarcer and more likely to go extinct.

As humans convert natural habitats, we lose species from the natural communities they once belonged to. One concern is that as we lose species, we lose more of the unusual species – those with few related species and those with rare functions in their ecosystems. This process can lead to the homogenization of natural communities, such that most are made up of the same wide-ranging species. This suggests that when making conservation decisions, we should consider all three dimensions of biodiversity. In other words, we should be protecting species with few living relatives (and therefore with more unique genes) and species with unusual functional roles instead of focusing solely on species. In fact, however, we found that representation of all three dimensions of biodiversity were strongly correlated across the Americas. This means that the current focus on species conservation likely serves as an effective surrogate for the other dimensions of biodiversity.

This project directly benefited 21 undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students who received international research experience and advanced their scientific careers. These students participated in designing research plans, conducting research and coauthoring scientific publications. Several students visited labs in universities in foreign countries, further strengthening and broadening their research experience.

Students and senior researchers contributed to 63 publications that have been published or are under review for publication in peer-reviewed scientific journals. These publications represent a permanent scientific record of the research conducted, and describe in detail the discoveries made during the course of the project.

The project also assessed the conservation status of over 2,200 New World reptiles, assigning IUCN Red List categories (e.g., Critically Endangered, Endangered, Vulnerable, Near Threatened, Least Concern or Data Deficient) to each of these species. The Red List data play an increasingly important role in global biodiversity policy. For example, they influence lending decisions made by the International Finance Corporation (IFC), a member of the World Bank Group. Red List data are one of the core knowledge products that power IBAT (www.ibatforbusiness.org), a global biodiversity decision support platform for businesses to use to reduce their environmental footprint. The Red List Index, which is calculated using data from assessments such as those that we contributed from this project, is a fundamental indicator for both the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals and the Convention on Biological Diversity’s Aichi Targets. Thus the research conducted not only helped answer some of the big questions facing scientists, but also contributed to the development of human resources and global conservation initiatives.
